sentence: SAP (NYSE:SAP) competes with Oracle (NASDAQ:ORCL), Salesforce.com ( CRM ) and Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) in the applications software market.
The applications software market consists of various applications like Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), Customer Relationship Management ( CRM ) and Business Intelligence (BI) to name a few.
These products account for 37%, 20% and 12% respectively of our $64 price estimate for SAP stock .
Our price estimate is about 5% above market price.
Here we highlight 4 of the most important drivers for SAP's business and the upside as well as downside scenarios associated with each of these drivers.
SAP's share in ERP market : We estimate that SAP's share in ERP market has declined from around 29% in 2005 to around 27% in 2010 and we expect it to decline further.
SAP's share in CRM market : We estimate that SAP's share in CRM market has declined from around 26% in 2005 to 22% in 2010, and we expect to decline further.
SAP's share in BI market: We estimate that SAP's share in BI market has increased from 7% in 2006 to 24% in 2010, and we expect it to continue to increase.
SAP's BI market share increased suddenly in 2008 due to its $6.8 billion acquisition of Business Objects in 2008.
SG&A % of gross profits: This ratio declined from 42% in 2008 to 35% in 2010.
However, we expect it to increase going forward.
We forecast that SAP's share in ERP market will continue to decline to around 25% by the end of Trefis forecast period as has been the trend historically.
The on-demand market has demonstrated potential for rapid growth in the coming years.
We believe that players like Salesforce.com, Oracle and Microsoft have enjoyed an edge in this market because they jumped on-demand train a bit sooner than SAP.
However, SAP has started to gain traction in its Business ByDesign on-demand software.
The company has more than doubled the number of customers, from fewer than 100 to about 250, since launching the software in mid-2010.
SAP aims to increase this customer total towards 1,000 by the end of 2011.
There could be an upside of 7% to our estimate for SAP stock if its ERP market share increase to around 30% by the end of Trefis forecast period, instead of the decline that we forecast.
We forecast that SAP's CRM market share will continue to decline to around 18% by the end of Trefis forecast period.
Pure cloud computing players like Salesforce.com have an advantage over SAP as it can benefit from the expected growth of software as a service (SaaS) market.
SaaS works on the on-demand principle, which means that the enterprises can license only the amount of software required versus the traditional way of procuring the license per device.

However, SAP's Business ByDesign enterprise software solution has a few advantages over products offered by competitors as other players typically provide a piecemeal solution while SAP's offering is an integrated solution.
There could be an upside of 6% to our estimate for SAP stock if its CRM market share increase to around 25% by the end of Trefis forecast period, instead of the decline that we forecast.
We forecast that SAP's share in BI market will continue to increase to around 26% by the end of Trefis forecast period.
SAP has made rapid strides in this market and gained share at a fast rate in the past.
Time and again SAP has mentioned that its in-memory is a disruptive technology, which speeds up data storage and retrieval to unprecedented speeds.
Leveraging the in-memory technology is a software known as HANA (High Performance Analytic Appliance) that SAP released a few months back.
HANA uses a different method of storing and retrieving data by storing it on computer's CPU rather than traditional way of reading and writing on storage disks.
If SAP's technology indeed becomes disruptive, SAP could gain market share at a faster rate than what we forecast.
There could be an upside of 4% to our estimate for SAP stock if its BI market share increase at a faster rate to reach 35% by the end of Trefis forecast period.
We forecast that SG&A % of gross profits will increase to 42% by the end of Trefis forecast period.
This ratio has declined in the past from a peak of 42% in 2008.
However, in the past few quarters, SAP has introduced a few new and innovative products.

These innovations have come through higher spend on SG&A and R&D, which constitute a larger portion of the company's gross profits and hence play an important role in the overall valuation of the company.
If the company is able to control rapid increases in its operating expenses, its stock could benefit.
There could be upside of 16% to our estimate for SAP stock if SG&A % of gross profits remains constant at 35% throughout the Trefis forecast period.
Although we already forecast SAP's market share to decline, the decline could be much faster if SAP's Business ByDesign software does not gain as much traction as we forecast.
Leveraging SaaS market growth is important for SAP as this market is expected to grow at double-digit while the on-premise market is expected to show single digit growth rate.
There could be downside of 6% to our estimate for SAP stock if its ERP market share declines at a faster rate to reach 20% by the end of Trefis forecast period.
Pure cloud computing players like Salesforce.com have an advantage over SAP as it can benefit from the expected growth of software as a service (SaaS) market.
Additionally, Oracle has claimed that it is not only winning market share from SAP but also selling software at a higher margin.
There could be downside of 6% to our estimate for SAP stock if its CRM market share declines at a faster rate to reach 14% by the end of Trefis forecast period.
Although we forecast an increase in SAP's share in BI market, Oracle could spoilsport here.

Although SAP's in-memory technology has the potential to threaten Oracle by producing faster transactions, Oracle has also made great strides over the last year or so through the introduction of faster Exadata machines capable of producing millions of transactions quickly.
There could be downside of 3% to our estimate for SAP stock if its BI market share declines to around 18% by the end of Trefis forecast period.
SAP's SG&A and R&D expenses have increased at a faster rate in the last few quarters as it continue to spend more on producing innovative products.
Its operating margins declined from 22% in Q1 2010 to just under 20% in Q1 2011.

If SAP is not able to control the increase in operating expenses and in the scenario where SG&A as a % of gross margins increases at a faster rate to reach 48%, there could be a downside of 12% to our estimate for SAP stock.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
